DOC.brief_summary: Non-arthritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy is the most common cause of sudden visual loss due to optic nerve involvement in patients above 50 years old. As this problem can be considered as a sclera out let syndrome an there is no effective and successful treatment for it, we decided to do a neurotomy procedure and relax the involved optic nerve in order to achieve acceptable treating outcome.
DOC.brief_title: Neurotomy of Optic Nerve in Non-Arthritic Anterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy
DOC.criteria: Patients with nonarthritic anterior ischemic optic nerve Visual acuity more than 20/200 Other intra occular operations Passing more than 4 weeks of the problem Arthritic anterior ischemic optic nerve Age under 50 years Consumption of previous pharmaceutical treatment
